elements.content: Based on a semirigid tetracarboxylate ligand 5-(3,5-dicarboxybenzyloxy)isophthalic acid (H4DBIP), 11 coordination polymers formulated as [M2DBIP(H2O)4(μ2-H2O)]·6H2O [M = Mg (1), Co (2)], [Cd3(DBIP)2]·(Me2NH2)2·(H2O)3 (3), [Cd2DBIP(H2O)2DMA]·5DMA·5H2O (4), (InDBIP)·(Me2NH2)·3DMA·2H2O (5), and (LnDBIP)·(Me2NH2)·(H2O)2 [Ln = Eu (6), Gd (7), Tb (8), Dy (9), Ho (10), and Yb (11)] (Me2NH2 + = dimethylammonium cation; DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide) were synthesized under solvothermal conditions and characterized by single-crystal X-ray structural, thermogravimetric, and photoluminescent studies. Compounds 1–2 are isomorphous and feature 2-fold interpenetrating dia networks. Compound 3 possesses a rare (4,8)-connected anionic network with flu topology built from 8-connected [Cd3(COO)8] clusters and 4-connected DBIP4– ligands. Compound 4 is a 3D framework with pts topology based on 4-connected rectangular DBIP4– ligands. Compound 5 shows a 3D anionic framework with lon topology. Compounds 6–11 display a 6-connected uninodal net with msw topology. In the 11 structures, the ligand H4DBIP exhibits two different conformations owing to its flexibility, serving as 4-connected or 6-connected nodes in the resultant structures. Luminescent properties have also been investigated.

Compounds 1-2 are isomorphous and feature 2-fold interpenetrating dia networks. Compound 3 possesses a rare (4,8)-connected anionic network with flu topology built from 8-connected [Cd3(COO)8] clusters and 4-connected DBIP4- ligands. Compound 4 is a 3D framework with pts topology based on 4-connected rectangular DBIP4- ligands. Compound 5 shows a 3D anionic framework with lon topology. Compounds 6-11 display a 6-connected uninodal net with msw topology. In the 11 structures, the ligand H4DBIP exhibits two different conformations owing to its flexibility, serving as 4-connected or 6-connected nodes in the resultant structures. Luminescent properties have also been investigated.

elements.content: Eleven new 3D coordination polymers were successfully prepared based on a semirigid tetracarboxylate linker. These compounds display five topologies, which are dia, flu, pts, lon, and msw. The result demonstrates that the flexible ligand can adjust its configuration properly to meet the geometric requirement of the central metal atoms/clusters, which results in a variety of fascinating coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: Eleven new 3D coordination polymers were successfully prepared based on a semirigid tetracarboxylate linker. These compounds display five topologies, which are dia, flu, pts, lon, and msw. The result demonstrates that the flexible ligand can adjust its configuration properly to meet the geometric requirement of the central metal atoms/clusters, which results in a variety of fascinating coordination polymers.

elements.content: Coordination polymers have received considerable attention because of their intriguing topologies and potential applications as functional materials. So far, a large number of coordination polymers have been prepared by using various organic ligands, such as carboxylate acids, imidazoles, and pyridine derivatives. Because of the versatile coordination modes, aromatic carboxylate linkers are most used to construct coordination polymers, and the typical example is using rigid linear dicarboxylate acids of various lengths to construct a family of isoreticular coordination polymers with pcu topology based on Zn4O-based SBUs. Compared with rigid aromatic ligands, flexible multicarboxylate linkers enable the formation of frameworks with uncommon or even novel topologies and special properties because of their flexibility and conformational diversity. It is obvious that the employment of flexible linkers presents a direct approach toward the understanding of the structure–property relationship of coordination polymers. However, such an approach may increase topological complexities and may frustrate attempts at prediction of the resultant materials. Many factors in the assembly process, such as temperature, reaction duration, starting materials, pH, counterions, solvents, templates, and auxiliary ligands, may induce different conformations of the flexible ligands, and finally control the structure of the frameworks. Therefore, systematic research of the effect of these factors on the assembly process is still a key challenge to construct desirable coordination polymers by using flexible ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers have received considerable attention because of their intriguing topologies and potential applications as functional materials. So far, a large number of coordination polymers have been prepared by using various organic ligands, such as carboxylate acids, imidazoles, and pyridine derivatives. Because of the versatile coordination modes, aromatic carboxylate linkers are most used to construct coordination polymers, and the typical example is using rigid linear dicarboxylate acids of various lengths to construct a family of isoreticular coordination polymers with pcu topology based on Zn4O-based SBUs. Compared with rigid aromatic ligands, flexible multicarboxylate linkers enable the formation of frameworks with uncommon or even novel topologies and special properties because of their flexibility and conformational diversity. It is obvious that the employment of flexible linkers presents a direct approach toward the understanding of the structure-property relationship of coordination polymers. However, such an approach may increase topological complexities and may frustrate attempts at prediction of the resultant materials. Many factors in the assembly process, such as temperature, reaction duration, starting materials, pH, counterions, solvents, templates, and auxiliary ligands, may induce different conformations of the flexible ligands, and finally control the structure of the frameworks. Therefore, systematic research of the effect of these factors on the assembly process is still a key challenge to construct desirable coordination polymers by using flexible ligands.

elements.content: Recently, we have been interested in the use of semirigid multicarboxylate linkers, such as tetrakis[4-(carboxyphenyl)oxamethyl]methane, tetrakis[(3,5-dicarboxyphenoxy)methyl]methane, etc., to construct coordination polymers and to promote the investigation of the structure–property relationship. Many interesting frameworks with diverse topologies, such as dia, pcu, sxa, nbo, mon, scu, etc., have been observed. In continuation of this theme, we design a new semirigid tetracarboxylate ligand 5-(3,5-dicarboxybenzyloxy)isophthalic acid (denoted as H4DBIP hereafter), to attempt to build coordination polymers and to investigate their structure-related properties. Compared with rigid ligands 3,3′,5,5′-biphenyltetracarboxylate (H4BPTC) and 1,1′-azobenene-3,3′,5,5′-tetracarboxylic acid (H4ABTC) with a single conformation, the ligand H4DBIP may adopt diverse conformations because the 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) units can rotate freely around the −CH2–O– moiety (Scheme ). Under solvothermal conditions, 11 compouds formulated as [M2L(H2O)4(μ2-H2O)]·6H2O [M = Mg (1), Co (2)], [Cd3(DBIP)2]·(Me2NH2)2·(H2O)3 (3), [Cd2DBIP(H2O)2DMA]·5DMA·5H2O (4), (InDBIP)·(Me2NH2)·3DMA·2H2O (5), (LnDBIP)·(Me2NH2)·(H2O)2 [Ln = Eu (6), Gd (7), Tb (8), Dy (9), Ho (10), and Yb (11)] (Me2NH2 + = dimethylammonium cation; DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide) have been synthesized. In this contribution, we present the syntheses and detailed structure descriptions of the 11 coordination polymers along with topological analyses, thermal stability analyses, and photoluminescent investigations.

elements.content: All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. The ligand H4DBIP and compound 5 were synthesized according to the literature. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out on an Elementar Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One with KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Rigaku MiniFlex2 diffractometer working with Cu Kα radiation, and the recording speed was 5° min–1 over the 2θ range of 5–50° at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min using an SDT Q600 thermogravimetric analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded at ambient temperature on a Bruker Avance III spectrometer; the chemical shifts were referenced to TMS in the solvent signal in d 6-DMSO. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The simulated powder patterns were calculated using Mercury 2.0. The purity and homogeneity of the bulk products were determined by comparison of the simulated and experimental X-ray powder diffraction patterns.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. The ligand H4DBIP and compound 5  were synthesized according to the literature. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out on an Elementar Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One with KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Rigaku MiniFlex2 diffractometer working with Cu Kα radiation, and the recording speed was 5° min-1 over the 2θ range of 5-50° at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min using an SDT Q600 thermogravimetric analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded at ambient temperature on a Bruker Avance III spectrometer; the chemical shifts were referenced to TMS in the solvent signal in d 6-DMSO. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The simulated powder patterns were calculated using Mercury 2.0. The purity and homogeneity of the bulk products were determined by comparison of the simulated and experimental X-ray powder diffraction patterns.

elements.content: Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (0.10 mmol, 26 mg), H4DBIP (0.05 mmol, 18 mg), 5 mL of DMF (N,N-dimethylformamide), and 2.5 mL of H2O were placed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The mixture was heated under autogenous pressure at 85 °C for 3 days and then cooled naturally to room temperature. Colorless block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained by filtration, washed several times with DMF/H2O (v/v = 2/1), and then dried in air at ambient temperature. The compound is stable in air and insoluble in common organic solvents, such as methanol, ethanol, acetonitrile, acetone, and dimethylsulfoxide. Yield: 86% (based on H4DBIP). Anal. Calcd for C17H30O20Mg2 (M r = 603.02): C, 33.86; H, 5.01. Found: C, 33.84; H, 5.03. ν = 3488(br), 1664(s), 1548(s), 1448(s), 1391(s), 1269(m), 1046(m), 787(s), 744(s), 715(m).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of compound 1 were collected on a Mercury 70 (2 × 2 bin mode) CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å); the diffraction data of 2 and 5 were collected on a Rigaku Saturn 70 (4 × 4 bin mode) diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and a CCD area detector; the diffraction data of 3 and 4 were collected on a Rigaku Saturn 724+ (2 × 2 bin mode) diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å); and the diffraction data of 6–11 were collected on an Xcalibur, Eos diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). All absorption corrections were performed using the CrystalClear program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The positions of hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were generated geometrically. Attempts to locate and model the highly disordered solvent molecules and counterions in the pores were unsuccessful. Therefore, the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was used to remove the diffraction contribution from these solvents to produce a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. Details of the structure solution and final refinements for the compounds are given in Tables and . CCDC 862542-862545, 840567, and 871983-871989 contain the crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk.

Attempts to locate and model the highly disordered solvent molecules and counterions in the pores were unsuccessful. Therefore, the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was used to remove the diffraction contribution from these solvents to produce a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. Compounds 1–11 were successfully synthesized under solvothermal conditions for 3 days and reproduced in bulk. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies unambiguously confirmed the framework structures of the 11 compounds, where a combination of NMR, EA, and TGA analyses gave the formulas of them. The coordination modes of the H4DBIP ligand are shown in Scheme .

Result and Discussion

Compounds 1-11 were successfully synthesized under solvothermal conditions for 3 days and reproduced in bulk. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies unambiguously confirmed the framework structures of the 11 compounds, where a combination of NMR, EA, and TGA analyses gave the formulas of them. The coordination modes of the H4DBIP ligand are shown in Scheme .

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous and crystallize in the monoclinic space group C2/c. As a representative example, only the crystal structure of 1 is depicted here in detail. As shown in Figure , the asymmetric unit of 1 contains one crystallographically independent Mg(II) ion and two coordination water molecules at general positions, one coordination water molecule at a mirror position, and one DBIP4– ligand locating at the C 2 axis. The Mg(II) ion is six coordinated by an oxygen atom (O4) from a monodentate carboxylic group, two oxygen atoms (O2A and O1B) from two bridging carboxylic groups, and another three oxygen atoms (O6w, O7w, and O8w) from three coordination water molecules. The coordination environment of the magnesium center is best described by a slightly distorted octahedron. The two adjacent magnesium centers are triply bridged by a μ2-H2O and two bridging carboxyl groups from DBIP4– ligands, leading to the construction of a binuclear magnesium cluster [Mg2(COO)4(μ2-H2O)(H2O)4]. The coordination mode of the DBIP4– ligand in compounds 1 and 2 is shown in Scheme a. Interestingly, the two phenyl rings in the same DBIP4– ligand are exactly perpendicular to each other. In the structure, every binuclear magnesium cluster connects four DBIP4– ligands and every DBIP4– ligand connects four binuclear magnesium clusters, thus forming a 3D 2-fold interpenetrating framework with dia topology (Figure ).

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction study performed on compound 3 reveals that it is a 3D framework, crystallizing in the triclinic space group P1̅. As shown in Figure , the asymmetric unit of compound 3 consists of two crystallographically independent Cd (II) ions, one DBIP4– ligand, two free water molecules, and one NH2(CH3)2 + cation. The NH2(CH3)2 + is generated via either hydrolysis or decarbonylation of DMA under a solvothermal condition. The Cd(1) ion is bonded by six oxygen atoms from one chelating carboxyl group (O6C and O7C), one chelating/bridging carboxyl group (O1 and O2), and two bridging carboxyl groups (O3B and O9B), giving an octahedral geometry. The six oxygen atoms coordinated to Cd(2) are from two chelating/bridging carboxyl groups (O2 and O2F) and four bridging carboxyl groups (O4B, O4E, O8A, and O8D). Cd(2) lies on an inversion center and connects to two neighboring Cd(1) centers by a pair of μ3-O atoms in a vertex-sharing mode, forming a trimetallic cluster [Cd3(COO)8]. The coordination mode of the DBIP4– ligand in compound 3 is shown in Scheme b. Similar to 1 and 2, the two phenyl rings in the same DBIP4– ligand are also exactly perpendicular to each other. In the structure, every trimetallic cluster connects eight DBIP4– ligands and every DBIP4– ligand connects four trimetallic clusters, thus forming a (4,8)-connected framework with flu topology (Figure S9, ). A close inspection of the solvent-accessible surface discloses that straight open rhombic channels about 5.2 × 5.2 Å2 are present along the crystallographic a axis, which are filled with H2N(CH3)2 + counterions and free water molecules (Figure S10, ).

The Cd(1) ion is bonded by six oxygen atoms from one chelating carboxyl group (O6C and O7C), one chelating/bridging carboxyl group (O1 and O2), and two bridging carboxyl groups (O3B and O9B), giving an octahedral geometry. The six oxygen atoms coordinated to Cd(2) are from two chelating/bridging carboxyl groups (O2 and O2F) and four bridging carboxyl groups (O4B, O4E, O8A, and O8D). Cd(2) lies on an inversion center and connects to two neighboring Cd(1) centers by a pair of μ3-O atoms in a vertex-sharing mode, forming a trimetallic cluster [Cd3(COO)8]. elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 4 is a 3D framework, crystallizing in the monoclinic space group P21/c. As shown in Figure S11 (), the asymmetric unit of compound 4 consists of two crystallographicallly independent Cd (II) ions, two coordination water molecules, one coordination DMF molecule, and two DBIP4– ligands locating at inversion centers. Cd(1) is connected by six oxygen atoms from one chelating/bridging carboxyl group (O3, O4), one chelating carboxyl group (O1C, O2C), and two bridging carboxyl groups (O6, O8D). Cd(2) is coordinated by one oxygen atom (O11) from a coordination DMF molecule (O11), one oxygen atom from a chelating/bridging carboxyl group (O4), two oxygen atoms (O12w, O13w) from coordination water molecules, and two oxygen atoms (O7, O9D) from two bridging carboxyl groups. The coordination environments can be described by a severely distorted octahedron for Cd(1) and a slightly distorted octahedron for Cd(2). In the structure, the two adjacent cadmium centers (Cd (1) and Cd (2)) were triple linked by bridging/chelating-bridging carboxyl groups, leading to a binuclear cadmium cluster Cd2(COO)4(H2O)2(DMF) that is simplified as a red tetrahedron (Figure ). There are two crystallographically independent ligands in the structure; the coordination modes of them are shown in Scheme c,d. Different from compounds 1–3, the two phenyl rings in the same DBIP4– ligand are approximately in the same plane and the dihedral angle between them is around 0°. In the structure, the DBIP4– ligand is linked to four binuclear cadmium clusters in a rectangular fashion, simplified in a blue rectangle (Figure ). The binuclear cadmium clusters serve as 4-connected tetrahedral nodes, whereas the DBIP4– ligands act as 4-connected rectangular nodes, leading to the 4,4-connected binodal networks with pts topology. As shown in Figure S12 (), compound 4 possesses 1D square channels of about 10 × 10 Å2 along the crystallographic c axis. Because of the noninterpenetration of the framework, compound 4 possesses very large solvent accessible volumes of 55.2% of the unit cell volume, as calculated by PLATON after removal of free guest molecules in the channels.

elements.content: Compound 5 has been reported by our group recently. To demonstrate the structure versatility of the coordination polymers based on the H4DBIP ligand, the structure of 5 was also described here briefly. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compound 5 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmc21. The Flack value (0.24) indicates that 5 may be a twin crystal. As shown in Figure S13 (), Each indium(III) center is eight coordinate, binding to eight oxygen atoms from four different carboxyl groups, but serves as a tetrahedral 4-connected node due to the carboxylic groups adopting a bidentate chelating coordination mode. Each DBIP4– ligand links four separated indium(III) centers and thus acts as a tetrahedral four-connected node. Consequently, the framework of 5 shows a three-dimensional 4-connected uninodal anionic coordination framework constructed from mononuclear [In(COO)4] nodes with lon topology. The coordination mode of the DBIP4– ligand in 5 is shown in Scheme e; similar to that of 1–3, the two phenyl rings in the DBIP4– ligand in compound 5 are also exactly perpendicular to each other.

Crystal Structure of (InDBIP)⋅(Me2NH2)⋅3DMA⋅2H2O (5)

Compound 5 has been reported by our group recently. To demonstrate the structure versatility of the coordination polymers based on the H4DBIP ligand, the structure of 5 was also described here briefly. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compound 5 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmc21. The Flack value (0.24) indicates that 5 may be a twin crystal. As shown in Figure S13 (), Each indium(III) center is eight coordinate, binding to eight oxygen atoms from four different carboxyl groups, but serves as a tetrahedral 4-connected node due to the carboxylic groups adopting a bidentate chelating coordination mode. Each DBIP4- ligand links four separated indium(III) centers and thus acts as a tetrahedral four-connected node. Consequently, the framework of 5 shows a three-dimensional 4-connected uninodal anionic coordination framework constructed from mononuclear [In(COO)4] nodes with lon topology. The coordination mode of the DBIP4- ligand in 5 is shown in Scheme e; similar to that of 1-3, the two phenyl rings in the DBIP4- ligand in compound 5 are also exactly perpendicular to each other.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that compounds 6–10 are isostructural and crystallize in the chiral orthorhombic space group C2221. As a representative example, only the crystal structure of 6 is depicted here in detail. As shown in Figure S14 (), the asymmetric unit of 6 contains two crystallographically independent Eu(III) ions and two DBIP4– ligands locating at the C 2 axes. The coordination mode of the DBIP4– ligand in 6 is shown in Scheme f; again, the two phenyl rings in the same DBIP4– ligand are exactly perpendicular to each other. In the structure, every europium cation is eight coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two chelating carboxyl groups, another four coordinated oxygen atoms from four bridging carboxyl groups. The coordination environment of the europium center is best described by a slightly distorted bicapped trigonal prism. The two adjacent europium centers are doubly bridged by two bridging carboxyl groups from two DBIP4– ligands, leading to the construction of one-dimensional infinite helical {Eu(COO)4 –} n chains along the crystallographic c axis (Figure a). The {Eu(COO)4 –} n chains were further connected by DBIP4– ligands, forming 3D homochiral frameworks with one-dimensional square channels of about 7.0 × 7.0 Å2 that are parallel to the helical {Eu(COO)4 –} n chains (Figure S16, ). In the structure, every europium cation connects six DBIP4– ligands and every DBIP4– ligand also connects six europium atoms, thus forming a 3D 6-connected uninodal network with msw topology. As shown in Table , the nearly zero Flack parameter indicates the homochirality of the crystal. We successfully isolated both the right-hand and the left-hand helixes in the same batch, indicating the coexistence of left-hand and right-hand enantiomers in one pot (Figure a).

elements.content: Apart from crystallization in different chiral space groups, the structure of 11 is similar to that of 6. Again, the spontaneous resolution occurred during crystallization of 11, and two enantiomers for each compound, M- (minus or left-handed, 11-M) and P- (plus or right-handed, 11-P) helixes (Figure b), were found to be crystallized in the chiral orthorhombic space groups of P4322 and P4122, respectively. The Flack absolute structure parameters clearly indicate the chirality of the crystals (Table ). To further investigate whether the enantiomeric excess exists in these chiral crystals, the bulk samples of 6–11 were measured by a CD spectrum; however, each bulk sample of 6–11 showed a silent CD spectrum. All the results confirm that the resulting materials of 6–11 were racemic mixtures.

elements.content: Compared to the rigid tetracarboxylate linkers, H4BPTC and H4ABTC, which always adopt a four-connected rectangular node, the semirigid ligand H4DBIP can adopt either tetrahedral or rectangular nodes in the assembly of the coordination polymers, corresponding to that the two phenyl rings in the same ligand are perpendicular or parallel to each other. Combination with 4-connected tetrahedral metal clusters, 6-connected lanthanide ions, and an 8-connected [Cd3(COO)8] cluster, respectively, we successfully isolated coordination polymers with pts, dia, lon, flu, and msw topologies (Figure ). The result shows that possessing highly flexible arms with conformational flexibility, the semirigid ligand (H4DBIP) facilitates the formation of diverse topologies.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Diversity

Compared to the rigid tetracarboxylate linkers, H4BPTC and H4ABTC, which always adopt a four-connected rectangular node, the semirigid ligand H4DBIP can adopt either tetrahedral or rectangular nodes in the assembly of the coordination polymers, corresponding to that the two phenyl rings in the same ligand are perpendicular or parallel to each other. Combination with 4-connected tetrahedral metal clusters, 6-connected lanthanide ions, and an 8-connected [Cd3(COO)8] cluster, respectively, we successfully isolated coordination polymers with pts, dia, lon, flu, and msw topologies (Figure ). The result shows that possessing highly flexible arms with conformational flexibility, the semirigid ligand (H4DBIP) facilitates the formation of diverse topologies.

X-ray Powder Diffraction

To check the purity and homogeneity of the bulk products of compounds 1-11, the as-synthesized samples of the 11 compounds were measured by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) at room temperature. As shown in Figures S2-S6 in the , the peak positions of the experimental patterns are in good agreement with the simulated ones, which clearly indicate the good purity and homogeneity of the compounds.

elements.content: To investigate the thermal stability of these complexes, the thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a STQ 600 instrument in the temperature range of 30–800 °C under a flow of nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. As shown in Figure S7 (), because compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural, they show a similar thermal stability and are stable to about 85 °C. The continuous weight losses from 85 °C to about 170 °C correspond to the loss of all free water molecules (calcd: 15.92% for 1 and 14.28% for 2; found: 16.07% for 1 and 14.21% for 2), which is followed by a steady plateau up to 240 °C. The coordination water molecules start to depart from the frameworks above 240 °C. The thermal stability performed on 3 shows that a weight loss of 4.54% is found between 30 and 100 °C, which is in agreement with the departure of three free water molecules (calcd: 4.63%). A total weight loss of 47.56% from 30 to 370 °C observed for 4 corresponds to the loss of all guest molecules (calcd: 47.20%). Because of the similar structures of 6–11, these compounds almost have the same thermal stability (Figure S8, ). From 30 °C to about 150 °C, a total weight loss of about 6.15% is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules (calcd: about 6.09%). All of the complexes start to burn off with the loss of DBIP4– ligands above 400 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability Analyses

To investigate the thermal stability of these complexes, the thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a STQ 600 instrument in the temperature range of 30-800 °C under a flow of nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. As shown in Figure S7 (), because compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural, they show a similar thermal stability and are stable to about 85 °C. The continuous weight losses from 85 °C to about 170 °C correspond to the loss of all free water molecules (calcd: 15.92% for 1 and 14.28% for 2; found: 16.07% for 1 and 14.21% for 2), which is followed by a steady plateau up to 240 °C. The coordination water molecules start to depart from the frameworks above 240 °C. The thermal stability performed on 3 shows that a weight loss of 4.54% is found between 30 and 100 °C, which is in agreement with the departure of three free water molecules (calcd: 4.63%). A total weight loss of 47.56% from 30 to 370 °C observed for 4 corresponds to the loss of all guest molecules (calcd: 47.20%). Because of the similar structures of 6-11, these compounds almost have the same thermal stability (Figure S8, ). From 30 °C to about 150 °C, a total weight loss of about 6.15% is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules (calcd: about 6.09%). All of the complexes start to burn off with the loss of DBIP4- ligands above 400 °C.

elements.content: The solid-state luminescent properties, including excited/emissive spectra and luminescence lifetime (Table S1, ), of compounds 3, 5, 6, and 8 as well as free H4DBIP ligands were investigated at room temperature. As indicated in Figure , the strongest emission peak for the H4DBIP ligand is observed at 380 nm upon excitation at 290 nm. When excited at 290 nm, the emission maximum is found to be at 420 nm for 3, which is red shifted relative to the free H4DBIP ligands. By comparison of the emission energies and profiles of the H4DBIP and compound 3, the luminescent behavior of both 3 and H4DBIP are considered to be originated from intraligand π–π* transitions. On the contrary, the intense blue luminescence with an emission band peaking at 458 nm observed for 5 may result from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The difference in photoluminescence spectra of 3 and 5 may be attributed to the different coordination environments of the Cd(II) and In(III) ions.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

The solid-state luminescent properties, including excited/emissive spectra and luminescence lifetime (Table S1, ), of compounds 3, 5, 6, and 8 as well as free H4DBIP ligands were investigated at room temperature. As indicated in Figure , the strongest emission peak for the H4DBIP ligand is observed at 380 nm upon excitation at 290 nm. When excited at 290 nm, the emission maximum is found to be at 420 nm for 3, which is red shifted relative to the free H4DBIP ligands. By comparison of the emission energies and profiles of the H4DBIP and compound 3, the luminescent behavior of both 3 and H4DBIP are considered to be originated from intraligand π-π* transitions. On the contrary, the intense blue luminescence with an emission band peaking at 458 nm observed for 5 may result from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The difference in photoluminescence spectra of 3 and 5 may be attributed to the different coordination environments of the Cd(II) and In(III) ions.

elements.content: Complex 6 displays intense red luminescence and shows the characteristic emission bands for f–f transitions of the europium(III) ion when excited at 320 nm (Figure ). The strong intensity of emission at 617 nm in the red region is attributed to the 5D0 → 7F2 transition. The medium strong emission at 592 nm corresponds to the 5D0 → 7F1 transition, and the other medium intensity of emission at 700 nm ascribes to the 5D0 → 7F4 transition. The weak emission bands at 536 and 650 nm arise from the 5D0 → 7F0 and 5D0 → 7F3 transitions, respectively. The spectrum is dominated by the intense band of the 5D0 → 7F2 electron dipole transition, which is the so-called hypersensitive transition and is responsible for the brilliant red emission of the complex.

elements.content: In conclusion, 11 new 3D coordination polymers, namely, [M2DBIP(H2O)4(μ2-H2O)]·6H2O [M = Mg (1), Co (2)], [Cd3(DBIP)2]·(Me2NH2)2·(H2O)3 (3), [Cd2DBIP(H2O)2DMA]·5DMA·5H2O (4), (InDBIP)·(Me2NH2)·3DMA·2H2O (5), and (LnDBIP)·(Me2NH2)·(H2O)2 [Ln = Eu (6), Gd (7), Tb (8), Dy (9), Ho (10), and Yb (11)] (Me2NH2 + = dimethylammonium cation; DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide), were successfully prepared under solvothermal conditions based on the semirigid tetracarboxylate linker H4DBIP. These compounds display five different topologies, which are dia for 1 and 2, flu for 3, pts for 4, lon for 5, and msw for 6–11. The result demonstrates that the flexible ligand can adjust its configuration properly to meet the geometric requirement of the central metal atoms/clusters, which results in a variety of fascinating coordination polymers. These results also confirm the potential for synthesizing new coordination polymers of functional materials and for investigating their structure–property relationship by using flexible ligands. In addition, the thermal stability and luminescent properties were investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, 11 new 3D coordination polymers, namely, [M2DBIP(H2O)4(μ2-H2O)]⋅6H2O [M = Mg (1), Co (2)], [Cd3(DBIP)2]⋅(Me2NH2)2⋅(H2O)3 (3), [Cd2DBIP(H2O)2DMA]⋅5DMA⋅5H2O (4), (InDBIP)⋅(Me2NH2)⋅3DMA⋅2H2O (5), and (LnDBIP)⋅(Me2NH2)⋅(H2O)2 [Ln = Eu (6), Gd (7), Tb (8), Dy (9), Ho (10), and Yb (11)] (Me2NH2 + = dimethylammonium cation; DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide), were successfully prepared under solvothermal conditions based on the semirigid tetracarboxylate linker H4DBIP. These compounds display five different topologies, which are dia for 1 and 2, flu for 3, pts for 4, lon for 5, and msw for 6-11. The result demonstrates that the flexible ligand can adjust its configuration properly to meet the geometric requirement of the central metal atoms/clusters, which results in a variety of fascinating coordination polymers. These results also confirm the potential for synthesizing new coordination polymers of functional materials and for investigating their structure-property relationship by using flexible ligands. In addition, the thermal stability and luminescent properties were investigated.

cln_elements.content:
The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 4 is a 3D framework, crystallizing in the monoclinic space group P21/c. As shown in Figure S11 (), the asymmetric unit of compound 4 consists of two crystallographicallly independent Cd (II) ions, two coordination water molecules, one coordination DMF molecule, and two DBIP4– ligands locating at inversion centers. Cd(1) is connected by six oxygen atoms from one chelating/bridging carboxyl group (O3, O4), one chelating carboxyl group (O1C, O2C), and two bridging carboxyl groups (O6, O8D). Cd(2) is coordinated by one oxygen atom (O11) from a coordination DMF molecule (O11), one oxygen atom from a chelating/bridging carboxyl group (O4), two oxygen atoms (O12w, O13w) from coordination water molecules, and two oxygen atoms (O7, O9D) from two bridging carboxyl groups. The coordination environments can be described by a severely distorted octahedron for Cd(1) and a slightly distorted octahedron for Cd(2). In the structure, the two adjacent cadmium centers (Cd (1) and Cd (2)) were triple linked by bridging/chelating-bridging carboxyl groups, leading to a binuclear cadmium cluster Cd2(COO)4(H2O)2(DMF) that is simplified as a red tetrahedron (Figure ). There are two crystallographically independent ligands in the structure; the coordination modes of them are shown in Scheme c,d. Different from compounds 1–3, the two phenyl rings in the same DBIP4– ligand are approximately in the same plane and the dihedral angle between them is around 0°. In the structure, the DBIP4– ligand is linked to four binuclear cadmium clusters in a rectangular fashion, simplified in a blue rectangle (Figure ). The binuclear cadmium clusters serve as 4-connected tetrahedral nodes, whereas the DBIP4– ligands act as 4-connected rectangular nodes, leading to the 4,4-connected binodal networks with pts topology. As shown in Figure S12 (), compound 4 possesses 1D square channels of about 10 × 10 Å2 along the crystallographic c axis. Because of the noninterpenetration of the framework, compound 4 possesses very large solvent accessible volumes of 55.2% of the unit cell volume, as calculated by PLATON after removal of free guest molecules in the channels.

Thermal Stability Analyses

To investigate the thermal stability of these complexes, the thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a STQ 600 instrument in the temperature range of 30–800 °C under a flow of nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. As shown in Figure S7 (), because compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural, they show a similar thermal stability and are stable to about 85 °C. The continuous weight losses from 85 °C to about 170 °C correspond to the loss of all free water molecules (calcd: 15.92% for 1 and 14.28% for 2; found: 16.07% for 1 and 14.21% for 2), which is followed by a steady plateau up to 240 °C. The coordination water molecules start to depart from the frameworks above 240 °C. The thermal stability performed on 3 shows that a weight loss of 4.54% is found between 30 and 100 °C, which is in agreement with the departure of three free water molecules (calcd: 4.63%). A total weight loss of 47.56% from 30 to 370 °C observed for 4 corresponds to the loss of all guest molecules (calcd: 47.20%). Because of the similar structures of 6–11, these compounds almost have the same thermal stability (Figure S8, ). From 30 °C to about 150 °C, a total weight loss of about 6.15% is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules (calcd: about 6.09%). All of the complexes start to burn off with the loss of DBIP4– ligands above 400 °C.

A total weight loss of 47.56% from 30 to 370 °C observed for 4 corresponds to the loss of all guest molecules (calcd: 47.20%). Because of the similar structures of 6-11, these compounds almost have the same thermal stability (Figure S8, ). From 30 °C to about 150 °C, a total weight loss of about 6.15% is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules (calcd: about 6.09%). All of the complexes start to burn off with the loss of DBIP4- ligands above 400 °C.
